body:
There is a problem with downloading > 10GB files with ACD  #204 which I've worked out what is causing it, but I haven't had time to fix it yet.

This looks like it isn't related though.

What is the command line you are using?  Are you using `--bwlimit`?  If so #232 might be the cause.  It certainly looks similar though.

now that I think of it... I have both used --bwlimit AND not used --bwlimit.... when NOT using --bwlimit I got all the same 504 errors BUT each file only uploaded once... I do believe some of the files which were uploaded 2or3 times in a row (with each copy being presumably perfect) were with --bwlimit.

I'll generate a -v of one of these situations later, these huge files take me a long time to upload so I guess getting to the -v of the situation will take quite a while.
I have uploaded a new version of rclone a moment ago which definitely has the bandwidth limit fixes for amazon cloud drive.

I made a thread on the amazon developer forum here: https://forums.developer.amazon.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=10979

A log of this happening with `--dump-headers` would be very useful.  Remove the `Authorization:` header before posting it publically.
I'm also seeing this problem with large files >20gb ish. Using rclone-v1.29-linux-amd64

@santaclause88 if you can get me a log of it happening I can post it on the thread which might get some traction from amazon!

> A log of this happening with `--dump-headers` would be very useful. Remove the `Authorization:` header before posting it publically.

Here is a log. It has been trimmed up a bit to save some space. Let me know how else I can help. 
[log.txt](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/files/250454/log.txt)
@santaclause88 Thanks for that. I've given the forum thread some info from the log - lets hope Amazon take a look.

I have also seen this happening in the official amazon client for the mac: It uploads to 100%, then it gets a 504 gateway timeout and immediately restarts the upload. If you cancel the re-upload and look into drive, you will see that the file is already there.

So I think in the 504 case at 100% the behavior should be handled like the successful upload case and it should wait for acd-wait-time for the file to appear.

I'm seeing the same issue as reported. I was running with '-v' but not debug. Here's the tail of my log file if it is any help. While rclone was doing it's 24 retries I was also checking ACD with the web interface and didn't see the file.. however, when rclone started sending the file again from scratch, the file popped up in ACD.. not sure if that was just coincidence -- i.e. just took a little longer for the file to show up -- or if the retry triggered the file showing up..

[large-upload-error.txt](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/files/518531/large-upload-error.txt)
Try Increasing --acd-upload-wait-time the default is 2m. It maybe needs to scale as the Suze of file. How big are the files you are uploading?
The file is ~35gb. I'll try uploading the same file again with a `--acd-upload-wait-time` of 15 mins and see if that makes a difference and report back..

I tried again and it looks like it took ~5mins for the file to be "seen":

```
2016/10/09 21:30:01 video.m2ts: Object not found - waiting (40/180)
2016/10/09 21:30:06 video.m2ts: Object not found - waiting (41/180)
2016/10/09 21:30:11 video.m2ts: Object not found - waiting (42/180)
2016/10/09 21:30:16 video.m2ts: Object not found - waiting (43/180)
2016/10/09 21:30:21 video.m2ts: Object found with correct size - returning with no error
2016/10/09 21:30:21 video.m2ts: Copied (new)
2016/10/09 21:30:21
Transferred:   32.773 GBytes (3.282 MBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            1
Elapsed time:  2h50m25.2s
2016/10/09 21:30:21 Go routines at exit 4
```

Anyone else seeing similar behavior? Perhaps an increase in default from 2 mins may be warranted?

I think there's a relation between the size of the file and the time it takes to show up. Maybe rclone could add a log message that logs the relation of file size to how long it took for the file to appear. After gathering that data for some time it could be used to derive a common formula for the default wait time. Something like x-seconds + (m-seconds/gigabyte \* n-gigabytes).
@felixbuenemann good idea.  I'll put that in then we can do a bit of testing.

@ncw Btw. I noticed that rclone also re-uploads a file if it gets rate-limited at the end of the upload, because it doesn't jump into the wait-for-upload code in that case, so even though the file uploaded fine it is re-uploaded anyways.

Should I open a new issue for that case?
@felixbuenemann I've fixed that already - try the latest beta: http://beta.rclone.org
